Name: Check Point Full Disk Encryption

Name: Cryptoloop
First released: 2003-07-02<ref>Initial cryptoloop patches for the Linux 2.5 development kernel: </ref>

Name: Cryptsetup / Dmsetup
First released: 2004-03-11<ref>dm-crypt was first included in Linux kernel version 2.6.4: https://lwn.net/Articles/75404/</ref>

Name: eCryptfs
Developer: Dustin Kirkland  Tyler Hicks  (formerly Mike Halcrow)

Name: SafeGuard PrivateDisk
Developer: Sophos (Utimaco)<ref name="LenovoPrivateDisk">Rebranded as ThinkVantage Client Security </ref>

Name: BitLocker
Maintained?: <ref name=dislocker>https://github.com/Aorimn/dislocker FUSE driver to read/write Windows BitLocker-ed volumes under Linux / Mac OSX</ref>

Name: CipherShed
Licensing: <ref>http://www.truecrypt.org/misc/freebsd Although CipherShed can be built under FreeBSD  it is not recommended to run it because of bugs and instabilities when CipherShed is attempted to be used</ref>
column10: <ref name="play.google.com">https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sovworks.edslite Third party app allows to open containers encryptes with AES-256  SHA-512 hash and FAT file system</ref>

Name: CrossCrypt
Developer: <ref>CrossCrypt - Only for the Microsoft Windows XP/2000 operating systems</ref>

Name: Cryptainer
First released: <ref>http://cypherix.com/downloads.htm PocketPC freeware release- SmartPhone beta available</ref>

Name: Cryptoloop
Developer: <ref name="freeotfe.org">http://www.freeotfe.org/docs/Main/Linux_volumes.htm FreeOTFE supports cryptoloop  dm-crypt/cryptsetup/dmsetup  and dm-crypt/LUKS volumes</ref>

Name: FileVault 2
Maintained?: <ref>https://code.google.com/p/libfvde/ libfvde supports reading FileVault2 Drive Encryption (FVDE) encrypted volumes</ref>

Name: LibreCrypt
column10: <ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nemesis2.luksmanager&hl=en_GB Third party app allows a user to open LibreCrypt compatible LUKS containers</ref>

Name: TrueCrypt
Licensing: <ref>http://www.truecrypt.org/misc/freebsd Although TrueCrypt can be built under FreeBSD  it is not recommended to run it because of bugs and instabilities when TrueCrypt is attempted to be used</ref>

Name: VeraCrypt
column10: <ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sovworks.eds.android Third party app allows to encrypt and decrypt VeraCrypt containers (only available in the paid version)</ref>

Name: ArchiCrypt Live
Developer: <ref name="ArchiCrypt">Secret-containers and Camouflage files ArchiCrypt Live Description</ref>

Name: BestCrypt
column6: <ref>Supported by the BestCrypt container format; see BestCrypt SDK</ref>
column11: <ref>Supported by the BestCrypt Volume Encryption software</ref>

Name: BitLocker
Maintained?: <ref>BitLocker Drive Encryption: Value Add Extensibility Options</ref>

Name: CipherShed
column6: <ref>Although each volume encrypted with CipherShed can only have one active master key  it is possible to access its contents through more than one header. Each header can have a different password and/or keyfiles if any (cf. TrueCrypt FAQ: Is there a way for an administrator to reset a volume password or pre-boot authentication password when a user forgets it (or loses a keyfile)?)</ref><ref name="truecrypt.org"></ref>

Name: Cryptoloop
First released: <ref name=dmcrypt-initrd>dm-crypt and cryptoloop volumes can be mounted from the initrd before the system is booted</ref>

Name: FreeOTFE
Maintained?: <ref name=components>FreeOTFE has a modular architecture and set of components to allow 3rd party integration</ref>
column6: <ref name=keyfiles>FreeOTFE allows multiple keys to mount the same container file via encrypted keyfiles</ref>

Name: n-Crypt Pro
column7: <ref name=ncrypt-bio>n-Crypt Pro does not use password authentication— biometric/USB dongle authentication only</ref>

Name: PGPDisk
column7: <ref>PGP private keys are always protected by strengthened passphrases</ref>

Name: Svnd / Vnconfig
column7: <ref>optional by using -K OpenBSD Manual Pages: vnconfig(8)</ref>

Name: TrueCrypt
column6: <ref name="truecrypt.org"/><ref>Although each volume encrypted with TrueCrypt can only have one active master key  it is possible to access its contents through more than one header. Each header can have a different password and/or keyfiles if any (cf. TrueCrypt FAQ: Is there a way for an administrator to reset a volume password or pre-boot authentication password when a user forgets it (or loses a keyfile)?)</ref>
